title: PedDet: Adaptive Spectral Optimization for Multimodal Pedestrian Detection
author: Rui Zhao (JD.com), Zeyu Zhang (The Australian National University), Yi Xu (Central South University), Yi Yao (NavInfo Co., Ltd.), Yan Huang (University of Technology Sydney), Wenxin Zhang (University of Chinese Academy of Science), Zirui Song (Mohamed bin Zayed University of Artificial Intelligence), Yang Zhao (La Trobe University)
relevance_why: The techniques for feature fusion and robustness in varying conditions could inform methods in audio processing under similar noise conditions.
background: Pedestrian detection under various lighting conditions using both RGB and infrared images enhances the ability to identify pedestrians in complex scenarios.
contribution: PedDet introduces an adaptive spectral optimization framework to solve pedestrian detection challenges by effectively fusing multimodal features, achieving improved accuracy under diverse lighting conditions.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods struggled with effective integration of RGB and infrared data, suffering under fluctuating illumination conditions.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work enhances detection by adaptively fusing features based on lighting, utilizing a Multi-scale Spectral Feature Perception Module and an Illumination Robustness Feature Decoupling Module.

key_innovation: The adaptive weighting system for RGB and infrared features according to environmental conditions increases feature extraction efficiency.
real_world_impact: Enhancing pedestrian detection accuracy has implications for improving road safety in autonomous vehicles and traffic monitoring systems.
limitations: No limitations were explicitly mentioned by the authors.

new_terms.Multi-scale Spectral Feature Perception: This module dynamically integrates features from visible and infrared images, adjusting for environmental lighting to optimize pedestrian detection.
new_terms.Illumination Robustness Feature Decoupli: This module helps isolate pedestrian features from background noise, thereby improving detection accuracy under varying light conditions.

open_sourcing: Code will be available at https://github.com/AIGeeksGroup/PedDet
